info.title: devopness API
info.description: Devopness API - Painless essential DevOps to everyone

tags.name: API Reference
tags.description:
This page contains the documentation on how to use `devopness` through API calls.
> Note: This documentation is not complete, so for missing parts or inaccurate API description please
>
> reach out to `devopness` API team.

## Introduction
devopness's API exposes all `devopness` features via a standardized programmatic interface. Through devopness API a registered Devopness user can perform every operation you can do on https://www.devopness.com web interfaces and mobile apps.

## Getting started
All you need to obtain a token and start consuming this API is a valid email/password registered with devopness.com.


The `devopness` API is based on HTTPS requests and JSON responses, organized around [REST](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_State_Transfer). Our API has predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts requests with [JSON-encoded](http://www.json.org/) bodies with arguments, returns [JSON-encoded](http://www.json.org/) responses, and uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs.

## Date format
All dates in the API use UTC and are strings in the [ISO 8601 "combined date and time representation" format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Combined_date_and_time_representations):
```
2015-05-15 15:50:38
```

## Errors
The devopness API uses standard HTTP status codes to indicate the success or failure of an API call. In general: Codes in the `2xx` range indicate success. Codes in the `4xx` range indicate an error that failed given the information provided (e.g., a required parameter was omitted). Codes in the `5xx` range indicate an error on the API servers and are very rare.

The body of the error response is a JSON in the following format:

```
{
  "message": "The given request data was invalid"
  "errors": { // Optional errors object, returned only when there are detailed error message to be shared
      "field_1": [
          "Optional error message related to field_1"
      ],
      "field_2": [
          "Optional error message related to field_2"
      ],
  }
}
```

## Responses
When a request is successful, a response body will typically be sent back in the form of a JSON object.
Exception to this rule is when a DELETE request is processed, which will result in a successful HTTP 204 status and an empty response body.

### Response codes
Response codes indicate success or failure of request processing.
Status codes from the `2xx` range indicate that request has been accepted.
If the returned code is from the `4xx` or `5xx` range then it reveals either problem with the request or unability to process data.
See below for a list of HTTP Status codes used by `devopness` API:

| Status Code   | Description   |
| -------------:|---------------|
| 200           | Ok - The request was successful
| 201           | Created - The request was successful and a new resource has been created as a result
| 202           | Accepted - The request has been received but not yet completely processed
| 204           | No content - The request was successful. There is no content to return, but the headers may be useful
| 400           | Bad Request - The server could not understand the request due to invalid syntax
| 401           | Unauthenticated - It is usally caused by using wrong or expired credentials
| 403           | Forbidden/Unauthorized - The used credentials do not allow access to the resource
| 404           | Not Found - The server cannot find the requested resource
| 405           | Method not allowed - The request method has been disabled and cannot be used
| 409           | Conflict - The current request conflicts with the current state of the server
| 415           | Unsupported Media Type - The request's `Content-Type` or `Accept` headers are not set to a valid format
| 422           | Unprocessable Entity - The request was unable to be processed due to validation errors
| 429           | Too many requests - The client exceeded the requests limit in a window of time
| 500           | Internal Server Error. Please contact the `devopness` team

## Routes and Endpoints
A route is a URI which can be mapped to different HTTP methods. The mapping of an individual HTTP method to a route is known as an endpoint. `devopness` API exposes, as much as posible, well standardized endpoints with resources and segments leading the path to access the desired resource data.

Each resource mentioned in an endpoint segment has its name written in the plural form, as we are always referencing a collection of objects, that might or might not be filtered by a single ID or extra query string parameters.

### Resources and nested resources endpoints
Basically there are two types of endpoints used in `devopness` API:
1) Resource endpoints:

**Pattern:**

`/collection/{resource_id}/[{action}]`

**Examples:**

| HTTP Method   | Example                            | Purpose       |
| -------------:|------------------------------------|---------------|
| POST          | /projects                          | Create new item
| GET           | /social-accounts                   | List all items
| GET           | /social-accounts/{account}/status  | Perform a custom action (`status`) for a single item
| GET           | /tasks/{id}                        | Get a single item by id
| PUT           | /applications/{id}                 | Modify an item
| DELETE        | /processes/{id}                    | Remove an item permanently

2) Nested resources endpoints:

Nested resources are used when there is a clear hierarchy between the parent resource and the subresource, or for convenience to make it easy and predcitable on how to filter subresources belonging to a parent resource.
In `devopness` API design we strive to avoid nesting resources more than 1 level deep + one action related to the child resource or to the relationship between parent and child.

**Pattern:**

`/parent-collection/{parent_id}/{child-collection}/{child_id}/[{action}]`

**Examples:**

| HTTP Method   | Example                        | Purpose       |
| -------------:|--------------------------------|---------------|
| GET           | /projects/{id}/servers         | List all items belonging/linked to the parent resource
| POST          | /projects/{id}/servers         | Create a new subresource item and link it to the parent object
| POST          | /parent/{id}/child/{id}/link   | Create a relationship between parent and child object when both items already existed but were not linked.
| DELETE        | /parent/{id}/child/{id}/unlink | Remove the relationship between parent and child resources, without deleting any item

## Expanding objects
`TO DO:` define the rules for object expansion and document it here

tags.name: Static Data
tags.description:
Client API applications might need to retrieve possible accepted values to fulfill their forms and allow end users to pick values from a list of valid data.
All static data that need to be used through `devopness` API client applications is provided through the `/static/*` endpoints.

tags.name: Applications - SSL Certificates
tags.description: Throughout the `devopness` documentation the term `SSL Certificate` refers to a public key certificate adhering to `X.509` standard. While TLS is the protocol more used nowadays for web encryption, for historical reasons web encryption is often referred to simply as SSL. A SSL Certificate managed by `devopness` might be used as an HTTPS/SSL/TLS and other internet protocols to establish encrypted connections between client apps (e.g. browsers) and the web application servers managed through `devopness`, but it's not limited to be used for authenticating server's identity.

tags.name: Cronjobs/Scheduled Tasks
tags.description: A cronjob or scheduled task is a scheduled command to be set on one or more project servers to ensure a given routine will be executed on time.

tags.name: Daemons/Processes
tags.description: The terms `process`, `background process` and `daemon` may be used interchangeably in the `devopness` API documentation to denote the same thing: i.e., a computer process that runs behind the scenes without user intervention, detached from TTY (teletype/terminal type) and having no associated console or controlling terminal, therefore prevented from receiving `SIGHUP` on shell termination.

tags.name: Projects - Cronjobs/Scheduled Tasks
tags.description: A cronjob or scheduled task is a scheduled command to be set on one or more project servers to ensure a given routine will be executed on time.

tags.name: Projects - Daemons/Processes
tags.description: The terms `process`, `background process` and `daemon` may be used interchangeably in the `devopness` API documentation to denote the same thing: i.e., a computer process that runs behind the scenes without user intervention, detached from TTY (teletype/terminal type) and having no associated console or controlling terminal, therefore prevented from receiving `SIGHUP` on shell termination.

tags.name: Social Accounts
tags.description: A social account is a third party login/authorization service connected to the current user's account. e.g.: Facebook, Google, GitHub

tags.name: Source Providers
tags.description: A source provider is a Version Control System (VCS)/Source Code Management (SCM) connected to the current user's account. e.g.: BitBucket, GitHub, GitLab

tags.name: SSL Certificates
tags.description: Throughout the `devopness` documentation the term `SSL Certificate` refers to a public key certificate adhering to `X.509` standard. While TLS is the protocol more used nowadays for web encryption, for historical reasons web encryption is often referred to simply as SSL. A SSL Certificate managed by `devopness` might be used as an HTTPS/SSL/TLS and other internet protocols to establish encrypted connections between client apps (e.g. browsers) and the web application servers managed through `devopness`, but it's not limited to be used for authenticating server's identity.

BearerAuth.description:
Some few endpoints do not require authentication, but pretty much anything else will require you to be authenticated.
To become authenticated you will need to request an API access token through the `/users/login` endpoint.

## Using an access token
Once you have an access token for a given user you can pass it along in the HTTP request header.
Alternatively, if consuming the API through a web application, the token can be sent in the `AuthToken` HTTPOnly cookie as part of the HTTP request.

status.description: The current status of the action

total_steps.description: The total number of steps to complete the action

current_step.description: The current action step being executed

current_step_message.description: A message describing the current step being executed

output.description: A memo/text with full action output log - when available

started_at.description: The date and time when the action started to be executed (left the `pending/waiting` status)

completed_at.description: The date and time when the action has finished execution

name.description: A domain name that points to application main web address. Can be a naked domain or any subdomain. If app has domain names `testing.my-app.com`, `staging.my-app.com` and `www.my-app.com` a possible good candidate for the application name would be the "naked" domain `my-app.com`

project_id.description: Numeric ID of the project that the application belongs to

source_provider_id.description: Numeric ID of the source provider account where the repository is hosted. Required when the `repository` field is informed.

repository.description: The name of the repository containing the application source code. Required when the `source_provider_id` field is informed.

programming_language.description: The predominant programming language used in the application source code

framework.description: The base framework on top of which the application has been implemented - if any

entrypoint.description: The applicaton initialization file/module/function from which the application execution starts. It might be a file name, a package manager script or a module/class/function exported by application code and invoked by a run time environment of the technology used by the application.

root_directory.description: The relative directory where package manager's manifest files (`package.json`, `composer.json`, `yarn.lock`, etc) are located. It needs to be set for applications where the actual source code is not located in the top level directory of the repository.

public_directory.description: The relative web directory where publicly accessible assets are located and the web content should be served from

source_provider.description: The source provider from where the application source code repository has been retrieved

deployment_settings.description: The list of deployment settings for each application environment

environments.description: The list of environments to which the application is linked to

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current application

type.description: The type of the deployment being triggered

branch.description: The name of the branch from which the source code should be retrieved and deployed

hash.description: The commit's full hash that uniquely identify a commit. Required when re-deploying

id.description: The Id of the given group of settings

application_id.description: The Id of the application to which the settings apply to

environment_id.description: The Id of the environment to which the settings apply to

blueprint_id.description: The Id of the optional blueprint that might contain technology stack specific settings

domain_name.description: The sub-domain through which the application deployed with these settings will be accessed

app_directory.description: The physical path of the applicaton code/artifacts on the deployed servers

default_branch.description: The version control branch that, by default, will be retrieved and deployed. This might be overriden by client apps API calls when actually triggering a new deployment.

deployments_keep.description: The number of deployment history, logs and artifacts to keep stored in both devopness servers and user's servers

install_dependencies_dev.description: Indicates if at deployment time we should execute package manager command to install dependencies used in development mode

install_dependencies_prod.description: Indicates if at deployment time we should execute package manager command to install dependencies used in production mode

push_to_deploy.description: Indicates if push to deploy webhooks are enabled for this application/environment, if so code will be deployed when commited to the default_branch

engine_version.description: The language runtime engine version to be used to execute this application code on the deployed servers

build_command.description: The command that should be executed once to build the application source code. If set, `devopness` will not execute it's own build process to resolve package dependencies and get the application in a ready state. It will be assumed that the user is an advanced user that knows what she/he is doing, therefore the command specified here will be run as is everytime the application needs to be started.

init_command.description: The start up command that should be executed every time the application needs to be started. If set, `devopness` will not generate it's own start up script. It will be assumed that the user is an advanced user that knows what she/he is doing, therefore the command specified here will be run as is everytime the application needs to be built.
init_command.example: `npm run production`, `docker run -d -P --name my_container_name my_image_name`, `php artisan serve -host=192.168.2.20 --port=8000`

listening_address.description: Useful, for instance, when deploying `docker` containerized applications. If the application is not initialized by `devopness` itself, the user should inform the address at which the application listens to external calls. The address can be an IP, IP:PORT, HOSTNAME, HOSTNAME:PORT or unix:PATH

key.description: The unique key used to identify the variable on the target

value.description: The value to be assigned to this variable when deployed to its target

description.description: A text describing the variable, provided by the end user

target.description: The target defining how the variable key/value pair will be deployed

type.description: The type of the key/value pair

encrypted.description: Indicates if the variable value should be encrypted by `devopness` in the deployment logs

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

key.description: The unique key used to identify the variable on the target

value.description: The value to be assigned to this variable when deployed to its target

description.description: A text describing the variable, provided by the end user

target.description: The target defining how the variable key/value pair will be deployed

type.description: The type of the key/value pair

encrypted.description: Indicates if the variable value should be encrypted by `devopness` in the deployment logs

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

name.description: The name of the dependency item

hash.description: The commit comment's full hash that uniquely identify it

message.example: Good developers always add messages to their commits

committed_at.description: The date and time when the commit has been submitted

provider.description: The source provider where the commit has been retrieved from

repository.description: The full name of the repository (`owner/repository`) to which the commit belongs to

branch.description: The name of the branch of which the commit was the head at the time of its retrieval

url.description: The direct URL for accessing commit details on the provider's web application

author_email.description: The e-mail of the commit's author

author_name.description: The name of the commit's author

source.description: Source/channel from which the deployment has been triggered

started_at.description: The date and time when the action started to be executed (left the `pending/waiting` status)

completed_at.description: The date and time when the action has finished execution

actions.description: The list of actions related to the deployment

steps.description: The steps that were meant to be executed when the deployment was triggered

type.description: The type of the deployment being triggred

applications.description: The list of applications to be deployed together

servers.description: The list of servers to which all `applications` will be deployed to

branch.description: The name of the branch from which the source code should be retrieved and deployed

hash.description: The commit's full hash that uniquely identify a commit. Required when re-deploying

order.description: The execution order of the given step

status.description: Current status of the deployment step

started_at.description: The date and time when the step started to be executed (left the `pending/waiting` status)

completed_at.description: The date and time when the step has finished execution

type.description: The type of the deployment being triggred

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

type.description: The type of the deployment being triggred

servers.description: The list of IDs of servers to which the action must be performed

message.description: The main exception raised by the server

errors.description: Optional error object containing details of the server error

field.description: Field name and respective error message

field_name.description: Error message specific to each field included in the errors object

example.field_2: The field 'field_2' is not of the expected type

params.description: Optional free form list of additional parameters to forward to API operation

name.description: The internal name/code of the language runtime

displayable_name.description: The formatted name to be displayed in user interfaces

engine_versions.description: The list of the supported versions of the runtime engine

frameworks.description: The list of supported frameworks built on top of the runtime engine

name.description: The internal name/code of the language runtime

displayable_name.description: The formatted name to be displayed in user interfaces

defaults.description: Default values that apply to apps created in devopness using this framework

build_command.description: The command that should be executed once to build the application source code. If set, `devopness` will not execute it's own build process to resolve package dependencies and get the application in a ready state. It will be assumed that the user is an advanced user that knows what she/he is doing, therefore the command specified here will be run as is everytime the application needs to be started.

init_command.description: The start up command that should be executed every time the application needs to be started. If set, `devopness` will not generate it's own start up script. It will be assumed that the user is an advanced user that knows what she/he is doing, therefore the command specified here will be run as is everytime the application needs to be built.
init_command.example: `npm run production`, `docker run -d -P --name my_container_name my_image_name`, `php artisan serve -host=192.168.2.20 --port=8000`

listening_address.description: Useful, for instance, when deploying `docker` containerized applications. If the application is not initialized by `devopness` itself, the user should inform the address at which the application listens to external calls. The address can be an IP, IP:PORT, HOSTNAME, HOSTNAME:PORT or unix:PATH

entrypoint.description: The applicaton initialization file/module/function from which the application execution starts. It might be a file name, a package manager script or a module/class/function exported by application code and invoked by a run time environment of the technology used by the application.

root_directory.description: The relative directory where package manager's manifest files (`package.json`, `composer.json`, `yarn.lock`, etc) are located. It needs to be set for applications where the actual source code is not located in the top level directory of the repository.

public_directory.description: The relative web directory where publicly accessible assets are located and the web content should be served from

output.description: The full text output log of executed tasks

name.example: HTTPS|SSH|"Opening MySQL port so desktop apps can access it remotely"

type.description: The type of network traffic to which this rule will be applied

protocol.description: The network protocol to which this rule will be applied.

ip_address_from.description: Starting range of the public ipv4 or ipv6 addresses that can access this rule

ip_address_to.description: Ending range of the public ipv4 or ipv6 addresses that can access this rule

port_from.description: Starting range of network ports to be considered by this rule

port_to.description: Ending range of network ports to be considered by this rule

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current network rule

name.example: HTTPS|SSH|"Opening MySQL port so desktop apps can access it remotely"

type.description: The type of network traffic to which this rule will be applied

protocol.description: The network protocol to which this rule will be applied.

ip_address_from.description: Starting range of the public ipv4 or ipv6 addresses that can access this rule

ip_address_to.description: Ending range of the public ipv4 or ipv6 addresses that can access this rule

port_from.description: Starting range of network ports to be considered by this rule

port_to.description: Ending range of network ports to be considered by this rule

id.description: The Id of the given background process

name.description: The name entered by the user (or auto-generated by `devopness`) to uniquely identify the process

command.description: The command line to be executed to start the process

working_directory.description: The working directory where the process will be relative to when performing disk i/o

process_count.description: The number of process instances of the program to run simultaneously

run_as_user.description: The name of the Unix user on behalf of which the process will run

auto_generated.description: Indicates if the command was auto_generated by `devopness` itself

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current daemon process

name.description: The name entered by the user (or auto-generated by `devopness`) to uniquely identify the process

command.description: The command line to be executed to start the process

working_directory.description: The working directory where the process will be relative to when performing disk i/o

process_count.description: The number of process instances of the program to run simultaneously

run_as_user.description: The name of the Unix user on behalf of which the process will run

auto_generated.description: Indicates if the command was auto_generated by `devopness` itself

type.description: The type of the project, usually indicating the main technology, programming language or base framework

logo_image.description: A base64 string representation of the logo image

logo_url.description: A URL path to the project's logo image

ssh_keys.description: The list of SSH keys added to the project

os_users.description: The list of the operating system users found in all the servers linked to a project

user_name.description: The name of the user/account on the Version Control System

full_name.description: The fully qualified repository name. Usually composed of user_name/name

html_url.description: The URL for viewing repository details on the provider's web application

repo_full_name.description: The full name of the repository (`owner/repository`)

ip_address.description: Public ipv4 address for server access

ssh_port.description: The network port to which the SSH daemon is listening to SSH connections on the server

user_id.description: The id of the user who created the server and to whom the server belongs

active.description: Tells if the server is active or not

actions.description: The list of actions related to the server

environments.description: The list of environments to which the server is linked to

databases.description: The list of databases that must be installed on the server

providers.description: The list of tools that must be made available on the server

tools.description: The list of tools that must be made available on the server

connect_command.description: The Shell Script command to be executed in an existing Linux server in order to connect it to the `devopness`

message.description: Output message indicating success or failure

hostname.description: The hostname to be set on Linux servers. Accepts numbers (0-9), dash (-) and lower case non accented characters

ip_address.description: Public ipv4 address for server access

ssh_port.description: The network port to which the SSH daemon is listening to SSH connections on the server

actions.description: The list of actions related to the server

displayable_name.description: Formatted/human readable version of the service name

auto_generated.description: Indicates if the service was auto_generated by `devopness` itself

auto_start.description: Indicates if the service is marked for start automatically on operating system boot

initial_state.description: The expected initial state of the service after installed

description.description: A text describing the service, provided by the service author

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current service

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

auto_start.description: Indicates if the service is marked for start automatically on operating system boot

initial_state.description: The expected initial state of the service after installed

provider.description: The name of the Social Authentication provider

provider_user_name.description: The name of the user on the Social Authentication provider

is_vcs.description: Tells if the social account provider is a Source Code Provider/Version Control System. e.g. false for Facebook, true for Github

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

provider.description: The name of the Social Authentication provider

callback_code.description: The temporary code forwarded by the OAuth provider as a parameter to our callback URL

provider.description: The name of the Social Authentication provider

connected.description: Tells if the provider is already connected to the current user's account

connect_url.description: A URL path to the provider's OAuth page

id.description: The Id of the given SSH public key

name.description: The name entered by the user to uniquely identify the public SSH key

user_id.description: The Id of the user to which the SSH key belongs to

public_key.description: The public SSH key to add to your `devopness` account and associate it to the given project

fingerprint.description: The hashed fingerprint of the public key

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current key

domains.description: The list of domain names to which the SSL certificate refers to

issuer.description: The entity or certification authority (CA) who issued the certificate

type.description: The certificate type, indicating its scope

validation_level.description: The level of validation applied when issuing the certificate. This can be one out of the three validation levels conforming to public key certificates standards: `DV (Domain Validation)`, `OV (Organization validation)` or `EV (Extended Validation)`

custom_private_key.description: The private key provided by the Certification Authority, when the certificate has not being automatically issued through `devopness`

custom_certificate.description: The contents of the certificate provided by the Certification Authority, when the certificate has not being automatically issued through `devopness`

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current certificate

active.description: Tells if the certificate is active for all linked servers and applications

user_id.description: The unique id of the user to which this record belongs to

expires_at.description: The date and time when this certificate will no longer be valid, down to minute precision

last_renewed_at.description: The date and time when this certificate was renewed for the last time

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

environment_id.description: The Id of the environment to which the settings apply to

domains.description: The list of domain names to which the SSL certificate refers to

issuer.description: The entity or certification authority (CA) who issued the certificate

type.description: The certificate type, indicating its scope

validation_level.description: The level of validation applied when issuing the certificate. This can be one out of the three validation levels conforming to public key certificates standards: `DV (Domain Validation)`, `OV (Organization validation)` or `EV (Extended Validation)`

custom_private_key.description: The private key provided by the Certification Authority, when the certificate has not being automatically issued through `devopness`

custom_certificate.description: The contents of the certificate provided by the Certification Authority, when the certificate has not being automatically issued through `devopness`

id.description: The Id of the given background process

command.description: The command line to be executed when running the task

pattern.description: A cron expression consisting of Minute, Hour, Day of Month, Month and Day of Week subexpressions

pattern_human_readable.description: A translation of the cron expression to a readable string indicating its execution frequency.

run_as_user.description: The name of the Unix user on behalf of which the task will be executed

auto_generated.description: Indicates if the task was auto_generated by `devopness` itself

status.description: Current status of deploying to remote servers the current task

command.description: The command line to be executed when running the task

pattern.description: A cron expression consisting of Minute, Hour, Day of Month, Month and Day of Week subexpressions

run_as_user.description: The name of the Unix user on behalf of which the task will be executed

auto_generated.description: Indicates if the task was auto_generated by `devopness` itself

id.description: The Id of the given user

email.description: The e-mail that will uniquely identify the user on the system and become its login credential

active.description: Tells if the user is active or not

created_at.description: The date and time when the record was created

updated_at.description: The date and time when the record was last updated

social_accounts.description: The list of social accounts (source providers + login providers) connected to the user

email.description: The e-mail that will uniquely identify the user on the system and become its login credential

refresh_token.description:
A token to be used after the original access token has expired, to issue a new token
without requiring a new request to the `/users/login` endpoint

token_type.description: The type of the authorization token being issued

expires_in.description:
The number of seconds remaining to the token expiration time,
to be counted since the token issue date and time

refresh_token.description:
A token to be used after the original access token has expired, to issue a new token
without requiring a new request to the `/users/login` endpoint

NotFound.description: The specified resource was not found

Conflict.description: The current request conflicts with server state
